briefdescription.para: Reset indices / reorder aux data after elements have been permuted.

detaileddescription.para:
beg
Start of the range of elements to process.
end
End of the range of elements to process.
This is a no-op for DataList.

briefdescription.para: Test if we can insert; raise an exception if not.

detaileddescription.para:
op
Description of the attempted operation.
In order to maintain type-safety, we can only allow insertions using the most-derived instance of DataList. This checks this by testing the m_isMostDerived, which is set by the constructors to true only for the most-derived instance. If the test fails, we call to potentially out-of-line code to continue.

briefdescription.para: Test if we can insert; raise an exception if not.

detaileddescription.para:
op
Description of the attempted operation.
This continues the test of testInsert. There is one case where m_isMostDerived may not be set correctly. If this container was made via copy construction, then all the m_isMostDerived flags will be false. So we call setMostDerived to set the flags correctly and test again. If the test fails again, then we raise an exception.

briefdescription.para: Clear m_isMostDerived for this instance and for all bases.

detaileddescription.para: Called from the constructor after setting m_isMostDerived.

briefdescription.para: Set m_isMostDerived for this instance and clear it for all bases.

detaileddescription.para: Called from testInsert if the test fails. The flag may not have been set if this container was made via copy construction, so set it appropriately now so we can test again.

briefdescription.para: Find the most-derived DataList class in the hierarchy.

detaileddescription.para: The type_info for the class for which this method gets run. In order to properly type-check insertions, we need to be able to find the most-derived DataList class in the inheritance hierarchy. That's the purpose of this function. Every DataList defines this virtual method, so when it's called, the one corresponding to the most-derived DataList gets run.

briefdescription.para: Handle element assignment.

detaileddescription.para:
pos
Position in the container to assign.
newElem
The new element to assign.
The old element is freed if this container owns elements.

briefdescription.para: Handle element assignment from a base pointer.

detaileddescription.para:
pos
Position in the container to assign.
newElem
The new element to assign.
The old element is freed if this container owns elements.

briefdescription.para: Helper to shorten calls to DataList_detail::DVLCast.

detaileddescription.para: Helper to shorten calls to DataModel_detail::DVLCast.

p
The value to convert.
The value as a const T*. The conversion will be done with static_cast if possible, with dynamic_cast otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Default constructor.

detaileddescription.para:
ownPolicy
The ownership mode for the container.
By default, a DataList will own its elements. To avoid this, pass SG::VIEW_ELEMENTS for ownPolicy.

ownPolicy
The ownership mode for the container.
By default, a DataList will own its elements. To avoid this, pass SG::VIEW_ELEMENTS for ownPolicy.

Note that we do the complete initialization here in the derived class, using the default constructors for the base classes. The reason for this is to be able to deal nicely with the virtual derivation case. We can arrange to call the proper base class from here to get things initialized in the virtual derivation case. But then anyone who derives from us must also know to explicitly reference that base class. Doing the initialization explicitly here means that other classes who derive from us need only know about the most derived DataList class.

briefdescription.para: Sized constructor.

detaileddescription.para:
n
The size of the container.
ownPolicy
The ownership mode for the container.
Note that unlike the standard list constructor, you can't specify an initial value here. The container will be initialized with 0's.
By default, a DataList will own its elements. To avoid this, pass SG::VIEW_ELEMENTS for ownPolicy.

n
The size of the container.
ownPolicy
The ownership mode for the container.
Note that unlike the standard list constructor, you can't specify an initial value here. The container will be initialized with 0's.
By default, a DataList will own its elements. To avoid this, pass SG::VIEW_ELEMENTS for ownPolicy.

Note that we do the complete initialization here in the derived class, using the default constructors for the base classes. The reason for this is to be able to deal nicely with the virtual derivation case. We can arrange to call the proper base class from here to get things initialized in the virtual derivation case. But then anyone who derives from us must also know to explicitly reference that base class. Doing the initialization explicitly here means that other classes who derive from us need only know about the most derived DataList class.

briefdescription.para: Copy constructor.

detaileddescription.para: Constructor from iterators.

rhs
The container from which to copy.
This is a `shallow' copy; the new container will not own its elements. Constructor from iterators.
first
The start of the range to put in the new container.
last
The end of the range to put in the new container.
ownPolicy
The ownership mode for the container.
By default, a DataList will own its elements (and take ownership of the pointers passed to this constructor). To avoid this, pass SG::VIEW_ELEMENTS for ownPolicy.

first
The start of the range to put in the new container.
last
The end of the range to put in the new container.
ownPolicy
The ownership mode for the container.
By default, a DataList will own its elements (and take ownership of the pointers passed to this constructor). To avoid this, pass SG::VIEW_ELEMENTS for ownPolicy.

Note that we do the complete initialization here in the derived class, using the default constructors for the base classes. The reason for this is to be able to deal nicely with the virtual derivation case. We can arrange to call the proper base class from here to get things initialized in the virtual derivation case. But then anyone who derives from us must also know to explicitly reference that base class. Doing the initialization explicitly here means that other classes who derive from us need only know about the most derived DataList class.

memberdef.definition: DataList< T, BASE > & DataList< T, BASE >::operator=
memberdef.name: operator=

briefdescription.para: Assignment operator.

detaileddescription.para:
rhs
The DataList from which to assign.
This object. This is a `shallow' copy; after the completion of this, the DataList will not own its elements. Any elements it owned prior to this call will be released.
Note: this method may only be called using the most derived DataList in the hierarchy.

rhs
The DataList from which to assign.
This object. This is a `shallow' copy; after the completion of this, the DataList will not own its elements. Any elements it owned prior to this call will be released.
Note: this method may only be called using the most derived DataList in the hierarchy.

briefdescription.para: Assign from iterators.

detaileddescription.para:
first
The start of the range to put in the container.
last
The end of the range to put in the container.
Any existing owned elements will be released. The DataList's ownership policy determines whether it will take ownership of the new elements.

briefdescription.para: Access the first element in the collection as an rvalue.

detaileddescription.para: The first element in the collection. No checking is done to ensure that the container is not empty. Note that we return a const T* rather than a reference.

briefdescription.para: Access the last element in the collection as an rvalue.

detaileddescription.para: The last element in the collection. No checking is done to ensure that the container is not empty. Note that we return a const T* rather than a reference.

memberdef.definition: DataList< T, BASE >::ElementProxy DataList< T, BASE >::front
memberdef.name: front

briefdescription.para: Access the first element in the collection as an lvalue.

detaileddescription.para: Proxy to the first element in the collection. No checking is done to ensure that the container is not empty. Note that we return a proxy object rather than a reference; the proxy will handle deleting an owned element if it's assigned to.

memberdef.definition: DataList< T, BASE >::ElementProxy DataList< T, BASE >::back
memberdef.name: back

briefdescription.para: Access the last element in the collection as an lvalue.

detaileddescription.para: Proxy to the last element in the collection. No checking is done to ensure that the container is not empty. Note that we return a proxy object rather than a reference; the proxy will handle deleting an owned element if it's assigned to.

memberdef.definition: DataList< T, BASE >::const_iterator DataList< T, BASE >::begin
memberdef.name: begin

briefdescription.para: Return a const_iterator pointing at the beginning of the collection.

detaileddescription.para: A const_iterator. Note that dereferencing the iterator will yield a const T* rather than a reference.

memberdef.definition: DataList< T, BASE >::const_iterator DataList< T, BASE >::end
memberdef.name: end

briefdescription.para: Return a const_iterator pointing past the end of the collection.

detaileddescription.para: A const_iterator. Note that dereferencing the iterator will yield a const T* rather than a reference.

memberdef.definition: DataList< T, BASE >::iterator DataList< T, BASE >::begin
memberdef.name: begin

briefdescription.para: Return an iterator pointing at the beginning of the collection.

detaileddescription.para: An iterator. Note that dereferencing the iterator will yield a proxy rather than a reference; the proxy will handle deleting an owned element if it's assigned to.

memberdef.definition: DataList< T, BASE >::iterator DataList< T, BASE >::end
memberdef.name: end

briefdescription.para: Return an iterator pointing past the end of the collection.

detaileddescription.para: An iterator. Note that dereferencing the iterator will yield a proxy rather than a reference; the proxy will handle deleting an owned element if it's assigned to.

memberdef.name: rbegin

briefdescription.para: Return a const_reverse_iterator pointing past the end of the collection.

detaileddescription.para: A const_reverse_iterator. Note that dereferencing the iterator will yield a const T* rather than a reference.

memberdef.name: rend

briefdescription.para: Return a const_reverse_iterator pointing at the beginning of the collection.

detaileddescription.para: A const_reverse_iterator. Note that dereferencing the iterator will yield a const T* rather than a reference.

memberdef.name: rbegin

briefdescription.para: Return a reverse_iterator pointing past the end of the collection.

detaileddescription.para: A reverse_iterator. Note that dereferencing the iterator will yield a proxy rather than a reference; the proxy will handle deleting an owned element if it's assigned to.

memberdef.definition: DataList< T, BASE >::reverse_iterator DataList< T, BASE >::rend
memberdef.name: rend

briefdescription.para: Return a reverse_iterator pointing at the beginning of the collection.

detaileddescription.para: A reverse_iterator. Note that dereferencing the iterator will yield a proxy rather than a reference; the proxy will handle deleting an owned element if it's assigned to.

briefdescription.para: Add an element at the beginning of the collection.

detaileddescription.para: Add an element to the beginning of the collection.

pElem
The element to add to the collection.
The container's ownership policy will determine if it takes ownership of the new element.
Note: this method may only be called using the most derived DataList in the hierarchy.

briefdescription.para: Add an element to the end of the collection.

detaileddescription.para:
pElem
The element to add to the collection.
The container's ownership policy will determine if it takes ownership of the new element.
Note: this method may only be called using the most derived DataList in the hierarchy.

memberdef.definition: DataList< T, BASE >::iterator DataList< T, BASE >::insert
memberdef.name: insert

briefdescription.para: Add a new element to the collection.

detaileddescription.para:
position
Iterator before which the element will be added.
pElem
The element to add to the collection.
An iterator that points to the inserted data. The container's ownership policy will determine if it takes ownership of the new element.
Note: this method may only be called using the most derived DataList in the hierarchy.

briefdescription.para: Add a group of new elements to the collection.

detaileddescription.para:
position
Iterator before which the element will be added.
first
The start of the range to put in the container.
last
The end of the range to put in the container.
The container's ownership policy will determine if it takes ownership of the new element.
Note: this method may only be called using the most derived DataList in the hierarchy.

memberdef.definition: DataList< T, BASE >::iterator DataList< T, BASE >::erase
memberdef.name: erase

briefdescription.para: Remove element at a given position.

detaileddescription.para:
position
Iterator pointing to the element to be removed.
An iterator pointing to the next element (or end()). If the container owns its elements, then the pointed-to element will be deleted.

memberdef.definition: DataList< T, BASE >::iterator DataList< T, BASE >::erase
memberdef.name: erase

briefdescription.para: Remove a range of elements.

detaileddescription.para:
first
Iterator pointing to the first element to be removed.
last
Iterator pointing one past the last element to be removed.
An iterator pointing to the element pointed to by last prior to erasing (or end()). If the container owns its elements, then the removed elements will be deleted. Any duplicates will be removed in this process, but don't rely on this.

briefdescription.para: Remove the last element from the collection.

detaileddescription.para: If the container owns its elements, then the removed element will be deleted.

briefdescription.para: Remove the first element from the collection.

detaileddescription.para: If the container owns its elements, then the removed element will be deleted.

briefdescription.para: Erase all the elements in the collection.

detaileddescription.para: If the container owns its elements, then the removed elements will be deleted. Any duplicates will be removed in this process, but don't rely on this.

briefdescription.para: Swap this collection with another.

detaileddescription.para:
rhs
The collection with which to swap.
Ownership is swapped along with the collection content.
Note: this method may only be called using the most-derived DataList in the hierarchy. The rhs must also be referenced using the most-derived DataList.

briefdescription.para: Sort the container.

detaileddescription.para: This just sorts by pointer value, so it's probably not very useful.

briefdescription.para: Sort the container with a user-specified comparison operator.
Swap the referents of two DataVector iterators.

parameterdescription.para: The first iterator for the swap.
The second iterator for the swap/

briefdescription.para: Insert contents of another list.

detaileddescription.para:
position
Iterator referencing the element to insert before.
l
Source list.
The elements of l are inserted in constant time in front of the element referenced by position. l becomes an empty list.

briefdescription.para: Insert element from another list.

detaileddescription.para:
position
Iterator referencing the element to insert before.
l
Source list.
i
Iterator referencing the element to move.
Removes the element in list l referenced by i and inserts it into the current list before position.

memberdef.argsstring: (iterator position, DataList &l, iterator first, iterator last)
memberdef.name: splice

briefdescription.para: Insert range from another list.

detaileddescription.para:
position
Iterator referencing the element to insert before.
l
Source list.
first
Iterator referencing the start of range in l.
last
Iterator referencing the end of range in l.
Removes elements in the range [first, last ) and inserts them before position in constant time.
Undefined if position is in [first, last ).

briefdescription.para: Remove all elements equal to value.

detaileddescription.para:
value
The value to remove.
Removes every element in the list equal to value. Remaining elements stay in list order.

briefdescription.para: Remove all elements satisfying a predicate.

detaileddescription.para:
p
Unary predicate function or object.
Removes every element in the list for which the predicate returns true. Remaining elements stay in list order.

pred
Unary predicate function or object.
Removes every element in the list for which the predicate returns true. Remaining elements stay in list order.

briefdescription.para: Remove consecutive duplicate elements.

detaileddescription.para: For each consecutive set of elements with the same value, remove all but the first one. Remaining elements stay in list order.

briefdescription.para: Remove consecutive elements satisfying a predicate.

detaileddescription.para:
p
Binary predicate function or object.
For each consecutive set of elements [first,last) that satisfy predicate(first,i) where i is an iterator in [first,last), remove all but the first one. Remaining elements stay in list order.

briefdescription.para: Merge sorted lists.

detaileddescription.para:
l
Sorted list to merge.
Assumes that both l and this list are sorted according to operator<(). Merges elements of l into this list in sorted order, leaving l empty when complete. Elements in this list precede elements in l that are equal.

l
Sorted list to merge.
Assumes that both l and this list are sorted according to operator<(). Merges elements of l into this list in sorted order, leaving l empty when complete. Elements in this list precede elements in l that are equal.

briefdescription.para: Merge sorted lists according to comparison function.

detaileddescription.para:
l
Sorted list to merge.
predicate
Comparison function defining a sort order (which must be strictly weak ordering).
Assumes that both l and this DataList are sorted according to COMPARE predicate. Merges elements of l into this list in sorted order, leaving l empty when complete. Elements in this list precede elements in x that are equivalent according to StrictWeakOrdering().

l
Sorted list to merge.
COMPARE
Comparison function defining sort order (which must be strictly weak ordering).
Assumes that both l and this DataList are sorted according to COMPARE predicate. Merges elements of l into this list in sorted order, leaving l empty when complete. Elements in this list precede elements in x that are equivalent according to StrictWeakOrdering().

briefdescription.para: Reverse the elements in list.

detaileddescription.para: Reverse the order of elements in the list in linear time.

briefdescription.para: Swap one element out of the container.

detaileddescription.para:
pos
The element in the container to swap.
newElem
New element to put in the container. May be 0.
oldElem
Reference to receive the element removed from the container.
Reference oldElem is initialized with element pos of the collection (no bounds checking). Then element index is set to newElem. If the collection owns its elements, then it will take ownership of newElem and release (without deleting) the element returned through oldElem.
Note: this method may only be called using the most derived DataList in the hierarchy.

briefdescription.para: Return the DV/DL info struct for this class.

detaileddescription.para: This can be used to make sure that it's instantiated.

briefdescription.para: Return the underlying std::list of the container.

detaileddescription.para: Reference to the std::list actually holding the collection. Note that DataList<T>::stdcont does not necessarily return a std::list<T*> if DataList inheritance is being used.

briefdescription.para: Return the ownership policy setting for this container.
Erase all the elements in the collection, and reset the ownership mode.

detaileddescription.para:
ownPolicy
The new ownership policy of the container.
If the container owns its elements, then the removed elements will be deleted. Any duplicates will be removed in this process, but don't rely on this.

briefdescription.para: Return the DV/DL info struct for this class.

detaileddescription.para: This can be used to make sure that it's instantiated.

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of elements in the collection.
Returns the size() of the largest possible collection.
Resizes the collection to the specified number of elements.

detaileddescription.para:
sz
The new size of the collection.
Note that this function differs from the standard in that it does not allow specifying the value of any inserted elements. They will always be 0.
If the container is shrunk, elements will be deleted as with erase().

briefdescription.para: Returns true if the collection is empty.

detaileddescription.para: This is the type of the underlying std::list (what stdcont returns).

memberdef.definition: typedef T* const& DataList< T, BASE >::const_reference
memberdef.name: const_reference

memberdef.definition: typedef T* const* DataList< T, BASE >::const_pointer
memberdef.name: const_pointer

memberdef.definition: typedef const T* DataList< T, BASE >::const_value_type
memberdef.name: const_value_type

detaileddescription.para: The T value used as the template parameter. Note that this is different from value_type (that's T*).
This type is used to proxy lvalue accesses to DataList elements, in order to handle ownership.

briefdescription.para: Standard const_iterator.

detaileddescription.para: Standard iterator. Note that lvalue references here will yield an ElementProxy, not a reference.

briefdescription.para: Standard const_reverse_iterator.

detaileddescription.para: Standard reverse_iterator. Note that lvalue references here will yield an ElementProxy, not a reference.

memberdef.definition: typedef DataList< T, BASE > DataList< T, BASE >::self
memberdef.name: self

briefdescription.para: A helper typedef.

memberdef.definition: typedef ROOT_SELECTION_NS::DataList<T, DataList_BASE>::self DataList< T, BASE >::self
memberdef.name: self

detaileddescription.para: This is true for any DataList class if we need to use virtual derivation to get to the base DataList class.
This flag is true if this DL instance is the most-derived one. We set this to true in the top-level constructor; the constructor then calls clearMostDerived on the base classes.

memberdef.definition: DataModel_detail::DVLInfo< DataList< T > > DataList< T, BASE >::s_info
memberdef.name: s_info

briefdescription.para: The DV/DL info struct for this class.
Declare the transient variable(s):.
Remove consecutive elements satisfying a predicate.

detaileddescription.para:
BinaryPredicate
Binary predicate function or object.
For each consecutive set of elements [first,last) that satisfy predicate(first,i) where i is an iterator in [first,last), remove all but the first one. Remaining elements stay in list order.

briefdescription.para: Derived DataList<T>.

detaileddescription.para: This is used for the case where T derives from other classes. The list of pointers is actually held in the (unique) base class of the hierarchy.
See the file comments for full details.
